intro: Bothriocline schimperi var. tomentosa, commonly known as the woolly false dandelion, is a flowering plant native to parts of Africa. It is characterized by its hairy, grayish foliage and yellow composite flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in grasslands and disturbed soils, showing adaptability to various environmental conditions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often covered in fine, white hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. This variant is part of the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens.
